traffic_visible_response: 正在搜索找到 3 篇资料参考There are two possible interpretations of "China's Wailing Wall" as follows:- **Nanjing Massacre Victims' Name Wall** In China, the Nanjing Massacre Victims' Name Wall located in the south of the Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders is commonly known as the "Wailing Wall" or "Crying Wall" in Chinese. Designed by Qi Kang, an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and dean of the Architectural Design and Research Institute of Southeast University, it was established in 1995 with 3,000 names of the victims engraved on it, symbolizing the 300,000 compatriots massacred by the Japanese army. After several rounds of engraving, as of 2018, 10,661 names had been engraved on the wall.- **Dr. Li Wenliang's Weibo Page** After the death of Dr. Li Wenliang, a coronavirus whistleblower, his Weibo page (@xiaolwl) became a digital gathering space for Chinese netizens. So many comments were left on his final post that it was likened to the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem. Netizens left well-wishes, bared their souls, and shared their frustrations there.
